instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present
threads.message:
Hello all,

Am attempting to repair this board which has no green light.  It has all the G3H "always present" voltage rails except that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.1V.  It is not going past this state and S4 and other voltages from there on out are missing.  I can't see any shorts atm nor do i see an attempt at turning on and then shutting down because of a short.  It just seems dead.  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v and the one wire circuit seems to be okay.  I did have to cross ref the info for the LIO board where the one wire circuit is as I can't find the LIO schematic for this board.

Your help as always, greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present
threads.message: Tried another DC-in board/cable? History liquid drop etc? Sounds like corrosion under the SMC or bad SMC to me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present
threads.message: Yes forgot to mention that I did try another DC in board and cable.  Customer didnt mention liquid damage and I don't see any corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present
threads.message: Either corrosion under SMC, bad SMC, or bad <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> (less likely). Start by giving the SMC a nice light reflow be sure to remove the edge bonding well. If no change, replace from and identical <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present
threads.message:
Not really needed schematic for LIO board to check <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> circuit.
Easy to locate the two 5 pins chips there.
Then compare with <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 from 3115 board; or same circuit from available LIO schematic.
In fact, start checking voltage on Magsafe central pin (LIO board) and <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> line from MLB; you must get the same voltage.

8.1V points to SMC issue.
Disconnect LIO flex, keep only 5 pins DC cable connected.
Still 8.1V?
Try to reflow SMC, better reballing it.
